recipes.name: Kung Pao Chicken
recipes.description: A classic Sichuan dish featuring tender chicken, peanuts, and dried chili peppers.

methods.name: Marinate the Chicken
methods.description: Combine diced chicken with soy sauce, rice wine, and cornstarch. Let marinate for 15 minutes.
methods.tips: For best results, use chicken at room temperature

methods.name: Stir-Fry Preparation
methods.description: Heat oil in a wok until smoking hot. Add dried chili peppers and stir-fry until fragrant.
methods.tips: Be careful not to burn the chili peppers

methods.name: Cook the Chicken
methods.description: Add marinated chicken and stir-fry until golden brown and cooked through.
methods.tips: Don't overcrowd the wok to ensure proper browning

methods.name: Final Assembly
methods.description: Add peanuts and hoisin sauce. Toss everything together until well combined.
methods.tips: Add the peanuts last to keep them crispy

recipes.notes: This dish can be made spicier by adding more chili peppers or Sichuan peppercorns. Serve hot with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Mapo Tofu
recipes.description: A spicy Sichuan dish featuring soft tofu in a savory, spicy sauce with minced meat.

methods.name: Prepare the Tofu
methods.description: Cut tofu into cubes and blanch in hot water for 2 minutes to firm up.
methods.tips: Handle the tofu gently to prevent breaking

methods.name: Cook the Sauce Base
methods.description: Stir-fry garlic, ginger, and doubanjiang until fragrant. Add ground pork and cook until browned.
methods.tips: The doubanjiang should be cooked until the oil turns red

methods.name: Combine Ingredients
methods.description: Add tofu cubes and gently stir to combine. Simmer for 5 minutes.
methods.tips: Use a wooden spoon to prevent breaking the tofu

methods.name: Thicken and Finish
methods.description: Add cornstarch slurry to thicken the sauce. Garnish with Sichuan peppercorns.
methods.tips: Add the slurry gradually while stirring

recipes.notes: This dish is traditionally very spicy. Adjust the amount of doubanjiang and Sichuan peppercorns to your taste.

recipes.name: Sweet and Sour Pork
recipes.description: A Cantonese favorite featuring crispy pork in a tangy, sweet sauce with colorful vegetables.

methods.name: Prepare the Pork
methods.description: Marinate pork with soy sauce and rice wine. Coat with cornstarch and deep fry until crispy.
methods.tips: Double-fry the pork for extra crispiness

methods.name: Make the Sauce
methods.description: Combine ketchup, vinegar, and sugar in a bowl. Mix well until sugar dissolves.
methods.tips: Adjust the sweet-sour balance to your taste

methods.name: Stir-Fry Vegetables
methods.description: Stir-fry bell pepper and onion until slightly softened but still crisp.
methods.tips: Keep the vegetables crunchy for better texture

methods.name: Combine and Serve
methods.description: Add sauce to the pan, then toss in fried pork and pineapple. Cook until sauce thickens.
methods.tips: Add the pineapple last to maintain its freshness

recipes.notes: Serve immediately to maintain the crispiness of the pork. Best enjoyed with steamed rice.

recipes.name: Peking Duck
recipes.description: A famous Beijing dish featuring crispy-skinned duck served with pancakes, hoisin sauce, and vegetables.

methods.name: Prepare the Duck
methods.description: Clean and dry the duck thoroughly. Mix honey, rice wine, five spice powder, and salt to make a glaze.
methods.tips: Ensure the duck is completely dry for crispy skin

methods.name: Air-Dry the Duck
methods.description: Brush the duck with the glaze and hang to air-dry for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
methods.tips: Use a fan to speed up the drying process

methods.name: Roast the Duck
methods.description: Roast at high temperature (220°C) for 30 minutes, then reduce to 180°C for 1.5 hours.
methods.tips: Baste occasionally with the remaining glaze

methods.name: Serve
methods.description: Carve the duck and serve with warm pancakes, hoisin sauce, and julienned vegetables.
methods.tips: Serve the skin separately for maximum crispiness

recipes.notes: Traditionally served in three courses: crispy skin, meat, and a soup made from the bones.

recipes.name: Dim Sum - Shumai
recipes.description: Classic Cantonese dumplings filled with pork and shrimp, wrapped in thin wheat flour wrappers.

methods.name: Prepare the Filling
methods.description: Mix pork, shrimp, ginger, spring onions, and seasonings in a bowl until well combined.
methods.tips: Mix in one direction to create a sticky, cohesive filling

methods.name: Form the Dumplings
methods.description: Place a spoonful of filling in the center of each wrapper. Gather the edges and form a cup shape.
methods.tips: Keep the filling moist to prevent the wrapper from drying out

methods.name: Steam
methods.description: Place dumplings in a steamer lined with parchment paper. Steam for 8-10 minutes.
methods.tips: Don't overcrowd the steamer to ensure even cooking

methods.name: Garnish and Serve
methods.description: Top each dumpling with a small amount of grated carrot. Serve hot with soy sauce or chili oil.
methods.tips: Serve immediately to maintain the texture

recipes.notes: Shumai can be frozen before steaming. Add 2-3 minutes to steaming time when cooking from frozen.

recipes.name: Wonton Noodle Soup
recipes.description: A comforting Hong Kong classic featuring delicate wontons and springy egg noodles in a clear broth.

methods.name: Make the Wontons
methods.description: Mix pork, shrimp, and seasonings. Wrap in wonton wrappers, forming small pouches.
methods.tips: Seal the wontons well to prevent filling from leaking

methods.name: Prepare the Broth
methods.description: Simmer chicken stock with ginger and white pepper for 30 minutes. Strain and keep hot.
methods.tips: Skim any impurities from the broth for clarity

methods.name: Cook the Noodles
methods.description: Boil egg noodles until al dente. Rinse under cold water to remove excess starch.
methods.tips: Don't overcook the noodles as they will cook further in the hot broth

methods.name: Assemble and Serve
methods.description: Place noodles in bowls, add wontons, and pour hot broth over. Garnish with spring onions.
methods.tips: Serve immediately to maintain the texture of the noodles

recipes.notes: The wontons can be made ahead and frozen. Add 1-2 minutes to cooking time when using frozen wontons.
